Friday, February

21, 1935

The University Turns
The University is now celebrating
its fifty-ninth anniversary. Fifty-nine
in itself is not particularly startling:
sixty would have been better. And yet
it so happens that this otherwise undistinguished odd year marks a crucial point in the University's career.
At its founding, the Hopkins was a
little dream-place where men sincerely believed that the mind was splendid as well as respectable. It was the
foremost institution in the country in
the realm of higher scientific research — being a pioneer and, very
probably, the inspiration for the present army of research men storming
the barriers of the abstract. In practically all its branches, it led the
field. And in the course of its history,
four presidents — four distinguished
scholars—have maintained that original ideal to the best of their ability—
first, Dr. Gilman; second, Dr. Remsen; third, Dr. Goodnow; and now Dr.
Ames. A fifth will soon take his place
in the procession. Where will he turn?
That fifth miist face a somewhat
different Hopkins than that optimistic little school described above.
Through the lack of benificence on
the part of the Baltimore financial tycoons or maybe through other reasons, the Hopkins has undeniably lost
its leadership in many fields. The
Medical School alone stands with its
original glory.
But that is not for us to talk about.
Our little province is the undergraduate campus—and it hurts us to report that the mind is certainly not a
splendid thing here. College for most
of us is little more than a feather to
be plucked after four years and then
stuck into our caps. Wine and women
are exalted here as in the days of ancient Babylon. Even song is more-orless discredited; or, at best, subverted into a type of Indian tom-tom hysteria. In all truth, we can report that
President Gilman's noble thoughts
have descended through the chasm of
fifty-nine years — and, have been
crushed on the rocks of Levering Hall.
'rom the other side of the campus
conie other cries of "Down With Gilman." The workers are oppressed and
hutigry out in the world beyond the
walUs. And many of our colleagues
ha re identified themselves with these
mi Jerable ones. They have stepped
intc) their shoes. Thus, instead of being
pus'e scholars, they are half-ragamuffini3 and half-themselves. And it is
needless to say that that hungry-half
is E wretched thinker—and a bigoted
observer of all that enters its ken. A
hutigry man cannot afford to believe
the,t the mind is splendid. These collea,guest too, are no longer true to the
occ'asion they celebrate on this day.

No More Puns
We of the new editorial regime
want to make it perfectly clear where
we stand on puns. We want to inform
our readers in no uncertain terms.
Let us. declare ourselves now and forever. We hate them!
Our predecessors were not so sensitive. There were homely little artifices on every page. Double-meanings
and ludicrous ambiguities stared at us
from around front-page pictures. PreElizabethan devices adorned the headlines and the most dignified articles
like the bells on the cap of a PreElizabethan clown. You couldn't miss
them. You got tangled up in them.
And it was revolting.
To us, puns are fit preoccupation
for only the smallest of minds. They
represent an interest in the vulgar
paints of thought rather than in the
thoughts themselves. Puns are surface rather than content. They are an
escape from an intelligible communication. It is probable that the punster above referred to is much more
interested in a woman's cosmetics
than in the woman herself. A sad
state, indeed.
But, the most vicious application of
puns was evident in their use in moreor-less sacred places. A pun over the
picture of a venerable gentleman at
once introduces the absurd where it
doesn't belong. But the absurdity reflects not so much on the gentleman
as on the punster. He has jingled his
clownish bells where solemn robes
were required—and I'm sure he would
admit that solemnity is sometimes desirable. It's as if in Milton's "Paradise
Lost", Adam had quizzed his guest,
Satan, as to whether the devil really
believed that "the pun was there to
slay." Thank God that Milton had
better sense!
And that is not all. If that flippancy
were really an attempt to show the inherent smallness of things in the
great cosmos, then it failed miserably.
That punning business was just as
inadequate as the trite, little aphorism of Oscar Wilde. For example
Wilde said, "How pleasing to meet a
obscure person" — a flippant halftruth. But the world always said
"How pleasing to meet a distinguished person"—obviously, the other halftruth. Wilde then is just as witty an
shallow as the world. Ah, but the
whole truth! If we had real perception into the universe and wished t
make an appropriate remark, full o
profundity, we would in our turn exclaim, "My, but how pleasing to meet.
a member of the species."
—E.K.

Yale's New Coaehf 0.1
It is an athletic anomaly that Dr.
Ray Van Orman, All-American end
and nationally-known football coach
before he thought of lacrosse, should
further his athletic career as lacrosse
coach of a great institution.
Undoubtedly the quality of Yale
lacrosse will improve under Van's
guidance, but he will find himself in
the unaccustomed role of having to
teach the fundamentals of the game.
Furthermore, he will not find his cohorts as aclmowledgedly capable as
his old associates, simply because the
men at Hopkins are born with lacrosse sticks in their hands.
Because of this, no one should expect to see Yale threaten in lacrosse
ranks this year or even next year.
Only by inducing experienced high
school players to adopt Yale and thus
Initiate a wave of lacrosse interest
can that institution ever hope to rival
a Maryland college in the old Indian
game.
However, if Van can succeed in
spreading enthusiasm for the sport
among the good people of New Haven
he may surprise yet. At any rate, he
should enjoy the position of former
Hopkins man against former St.
John's man when he leads his prodigies to battle with Billy Poole's Harvard ten.

wishes of all his former players and
associates travel with him to his new
surroundings. We believe that Dr.

By HYMAN M. LEVIN
With a definite conception of what
a university should be, with no pretentious buildings to house the institution, and with a notable faculty of
seven professors, Daniel Coit Gilman,
the first president of the Johns Hopkins University, exactly fifty-nine
years ago, tackled the herculean task
of giving to the University a start in
the world of higher learning.
He did his job well. The University
was launched in 1876. Adhering
closely to their principles, Gilman and
his associates put their heart and
soul into the job and even in less
than half a dozen years' existence the
Johns Hopkins
. .. round the punctual sun
Has she, old Learning's latest
dunghter, won
This grace, this stature, and this
fame.
In speaking of the tasks which
faced the small original faculty, Gilman remarked:
"When I die, the memory of those
anxieties and perplexities will forever disappear. It is enough to remember that Sylvester, Gildersleeve,
Remsen, Rowland, Morris, and Martin were the first professors. As a
faculty, 'we were seven'. Our education, our antecedents, our peculiarities were very different, but we were
full of enthusiasm and we got together without a single discordant
note."
From the very inception of the
University 59 years ago, the first
president instilled in all of his associates the principal idea that in an
institution such as this there must be
freedom of method and a close contact between student body and faculty.
With the aid of the Board of Trustees and seven faculty members Gilman aimed at developing a university
of national and local influence that
would supplement existing colleges.
Through Gilman's efforts there were
attracted to Baltimore men of note
in the field of science and education
and students much interested hi higher education.
It was Daniel Coit Gilman who laid
down the fundamental principles of
the Hopkins. It was he who said that
the institution "should forever be free
from the influence of partisanship
. . . that the instructions should be
thorough, as advanced and as special
as the intellectual condition of the
country will permit, that the glory of
the University should rest upon the
character of the teachers and scholars here brought together, and not
upon their number, nor upon the
buildings constructed for their use;
that its sphere of influence should be

By KEN ZIERLER

Jay Natators Meet Villanova
Tomorrow, Face Manhattan Sat. In Two-Day Jaunt

It is ironical that the 1935 Jay
lacrosse team should find itself both
the weakest team and the team with
the most unsatisfactory schedule in
years.
If other colleges are afraid to play
Hopkins in lacrosse when the Black
and Blue ean offer only a sophomore
ten and when their chances for defeating the Jays are, consequently,
greatest, there is a fallacy in the logic
of these institutions. It seems to me
that any school would welcome a
chance to top a Hopkins lacrosse
team. It may be a long time before
another chance like this is offered.
Did the men who made out the '35
schedule point this fact out to the
colleges which ought to be on our
schedule?

Friday, February

21, 1935

The University Turns
The University is now celebrating
its fifty-ninth anniversary. Fifty-nine
in itself is not particularly startling:
sixty would have been better. And yet
it so happens that this otherwise undistinguished odd year marks a crucial point in the University's career.
At its founding, the Hopkins was a
little dream-place where men sincerely believed that the mind was splendid as well as respectable. It was the
foremost institution in the country in
the realm of higher scientific research — being a pioneer and, very
probably, the inspiration for the present army of research men storming
the barriers of the abstract. In practically all its branches, it led the
field. And in the course of its history,
four presidents — four distinguished
scholars—have maintained that original ideal to the best of their ability—
first, Dr. Gilman; second, Dr. Remsen; third, Dr. Goodnow; and now Dr.
Ames. A fifth will soon take his place
in the procession. Where will he turn?
That fifth miist face a somewhat
different Hopkins than that optimistic little school described above.
Through the lack of benificence on
the part of the Baltimore financial tycoons or maybe through other reasons, the Hopkins has undeniably lost
its leadership in many fields. The
Medical School alone stands with its
original glory.
But that is not for us to talk about.
Our little province is the undergraduate campus—and it hurts us to report that the mind is certainly not a
splendid thing here. College for most
of us is little more than a feather to
be plucked after four years and then
stuck into our caps. Wine and women
are exalted here as in the days of ancient Babylon. Even song is more-orless discredited; or, at best, subverted into a type of Indian tom-tom hysteria. In all truth, we can report that
President Gilman's noble thoughts
have descended through the chasm of
fifty-nine years — and, have been
crushed on the rocks of Levering Hall.
'rom the other side of the campus
conie other cries of "Down With Gilman." The workers are oppressed and
hutigry out in the world beyond the
walUs. And many of our colleagues
ha re identified themselves with these
mi Jerable ones. They have stepped
intc) their shoes. Thus, instead of being
pus'e scholars, they are half-ragamuffini3 and half-themselves. And it is
needless to say that that hungry-half
is E wretched thinker—and a bigoted
observer of all that enters its ken. A
hutigry man cannot afford to believe
the,t the mind is splendid. These collea,guest too, are no longer true to the
occ'asion they celebrate on this day.

No More Puns
We of the new editorial regime
want to make it perfectly clear where
we stand on puns. We want to inform
our readers in no uncertain terms.
Let us. declare ourselves now and forever. We hate them!
Our predecessors were not so sensitive. There were homely little artifices on every page. Double-meanings
and ludicrous ambiguities stared at us
from around front-page pictures. PreElizabethan devices adorned the headlines and the most dignified articles
like the bells on the cap of a PreElizabethan clown. You couldn't miss
them. You got tangled up in them.
And it was revolting.
To us, puns are fit preoccupation
for only the smallest of minds. They
represent an interest in the vulgar
paints of thought rather than in the
thoughts themselves. Puns are surface rather than content. They are an
escape from an intelligible communication. It is probable that the punster above referred to is much more
interested in a woman's cosmetics
than in the woman herself. A sad
state, indeed.
But, the most vicious application of
puns was evident in their use in moreor-less sacred places. A pun over the
picture of a venerable gentleman at
once introduces the absurd where it
doesn't belong. But the absurdity reflects not so much on the gentleman
as on the punster. He has jingled his
clownish bells where solemn robes
were required—and I'm sure he would
admit that solemnity is sometimes desirable. It's as if in Milton's "Paradise
Lost", Adam had quizzed his guest,
Satan, as to whether the devil really
believed that "the pun was there to
slay." Thank God that Milton had
better sense!
And that is not all. If that flippancy
were really an attempt to show the inherent smallness of things in the
great cosmos, then it failed miserably.
That punning business was just as
inadequate as the trite, little aphorism of Oscar Wilde. For example
Wilde said, "How pleasing to meet a
obscure person" — a flippant halftruth. But the world always said
"How pleasing to meet a distinguished person"—obviously, the other halftruth. Wilde then is just as witty an
shallow as the world. Ah, but the
whole truth! If we had real perception into the universe and wished t
make an appropriate remark, full o
profundity, we would in our turn exclaim, "My, but how pleasing to meet.
a member of the species."
—E.K.

It is an athletic anomaly that Dr.
Ray Van Orman, All-American end
and nationally-known football coach
before he thought of lacrosse, should
further his athletic career as lacrosse
coach of a great institution.
Undoubtedly the quality of Yale
lacrosse will improve under Van's
guidance, but he will find himself in
the unaccustomed role of having to
teach the fundamentals of the game.
Furthermore, he will not find his cohorts as aclmowledgedly capable as
his old associates, simply because the
men at Hopkins are born with lacrosse sticks in their hands.
Because of this, no one should expect to see Yale threaten in lacrosse
ranks this year or even next year.
Only by inducing experienced high
school players to adopt Yale and thus
Initiate a wave of lacrosse interest
can that institution ever hope to rival
a Maryland college in the old Indian
game.
However, if Van can succeed in
spreading enthusiasm for the sport
among the good people of New Haven
he may surprise yet. At any rate, he
should enjoy the position of former
Hopkins man against former St.
John's man when he leads his prodigies to battle with Billy Poole's Harvard ten.

By HYMAN M. LEVIN
With a definite conception of what
a university should be, with no pretentious buildings to house the institution, and with a notable faculty of
seven professors, Daniel Coit Gilman,
the first president of the Johns Hopkins University, exactly fifty-nine
years ago, tackled the herculean task
of giving to the University a start in
the world of higher learning.
He did his job well. The University
was launched in 1876. Adhering
closely to their principles, Gilman and
his associates put their heart and
soul into the job and even in less
than half a dozen years' existence the
Johns Hopkins
. .. round the punctual sun
Has she, old Learning's latest
dunghter, won
This grace, this stature, and this
fame.
In speaking of the tasks which
faced the small original faculty, Gilman remarked:
"When I die, the memory of those
anxieties and perplexities will forever disappear. It is enough to remember that Sylvester, Gildersleeve,
Remsen, Rowland, Morris, and Martin were the first professors. As a
faculty, 'we were seven'. Our education, our antecedents, our peculiarities were very different, but we were
full of enthusiasm and we got together without a single discordant
note."
From the very inception of the
University 59 years ago, the first
president instilled in all of his associates the principal idea that in an
institution such as this there must be
freedom of method and a close contact between student body and faculty.
With the aid of the Board of Trustees and seven faculty members Gilman aimed at developing a university
of national and local influence that
would supplement existing colleges.
Through Gilman's efforts there were
attracted to Baltimore men of note
in the field of science and education
and students much interested hi higher education.
It was Daniel Coit Gilman who laid
down the fundamental principles of
the Hopkins. It was he who said that
the institution "should forever be free
from the influence of partisanship
. . . that the instructions should be
thorough, as advanced and as special
as the intellectual condition of the
country will permit, that the glory of
the University should rest upon the
character of the teachers and scholars here brought together, and not
upon their number, nor upon the
buildings constructed for their use;
that its sphere of influence should be

to an adjoining building, and filled
another room—Dr. Kelly explained
that surgery is but one of the many
Things that keeps him actively engaged.
Besides his very versatile interest
in missionary and medical work at
home and abroad, Dr. Kelly maintains
a boys' club in a little village near
his summer home in Canada—and
anlong its membership, over whose
sPiritual and material welfare he
keeps close watch, he boasts "five
Thieves and two burglars."
Dr. Kelly is interested in thieves
and burglars. "They're riot a bad sort
"hen you get to know them," he said.
Last summer his home was robbed.
They are pretty fine fellows; I go
Over to the penitentiary quite fre(10ently to see them."
Under the rose in his lapel he wears
a black button bearing a red question
mark. Pointing to the emblem, he exPlained that the question mark represents the most important question in
hfe: "What think ye of Christ?"
"Most religions are guesses—and
soroe of them are very foolish guesses," he added.

INTENSIVE TENNIS PROGRAM

By KEN ZIERLER

Jay Natators Meet Villanova
Tomorrow, Face Manhattan Sat. In Two-Day Jaunt

It is ironical that the 1935 Jay
lacrosse team should find itself both
the weakest team and the team with
the most unsatisfactory schedule in
years.
If other colleges are afraid to play
Hopkins in lacrosse when the Black
and Blue ean offer only a sophomore
ten and when their chances for defeating the Jays are, consequently,
greatest, there is a fallacy in the logic
of these institutions. It seems to me
that any school would welcome a
chance to top a Hopkins lacrosse
team. It may be a long time before
another chance like this is offered.
Did the men who made out the '35
schedule point this fact out to the
colleges which ought to be on our
schedule?
